result.markdown:
--- title: 'Essential Tools: Pandas' jupyter: python3 --- Pandas is the Python Data Analysis Library. Pandas is an extremely versatile tool for manipulating datasets. It also produces high quality plots with matplotlib, and integrates nicely with other libraries that expect NumPy arrays. Use of Pandas is a data science __best practice.__ The most important tool provided by Pandas is the **data frame.** A data frame is a table in which each row and column is given a label. Pandas DataFrames are documented at: http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/generated/pandas.DataFrame.html Get in the habit: whenever you load data, place it into a dataframe as your first step. ## Getting started ::: {#59de24c3 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import pandas_datareader.data as web from pandas import Series, DataFrame import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns from datetime import datetime #pd.__version__ %matplotlib inline ``` ::: ## Fetching, storing and retrieving your data For demonstration purposes, we'll use a utility library that fetches data from standard online sources, such as Yahoo! Finance. ::: {#6201fea9 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} import yfinance as yf yahoo_stocks = pd.DataFrame(yf.download('YELP',start='2015-01-01',end='2015-12-31', progress = False)) yahoo_stocks.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
Open High Low Close Adj Close Volume
Date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500
2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000
2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800
2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300
``` ::: ::: This is a typical example of a dataframe. Notice how each row has a label and each column has a label. A dataframe is an object that has __many__ methods associated with it, to do all sorts of useful things. Here is a simple method: ``.info()`` ::: {#cfdda85e .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} yahoo_stocks.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` DatetimeIndex: 251 entries, 2015-01-02 to 2015-12-30 Data columns (total 6 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 Open 251 non-null float64 1 High 251 non-null float64 2 Low 251 non-null float64 3 Close 251 non-null float64 4 Adj Close 251 non-null float64 5 Volume 251 non-null int64 dtypes: float64(5), int64(1) memory usage: 13.7 KB ``` ::: ::: ### Reading to/from a ``.csv`` file Continuing to explore methods, let's write the dataframe out to a ``.csv`` file: ::: {#ac986226 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} yahoo_stocks.to_csv('yahoo_data.csv') ``` ::: ::: {#6d3c8032 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} !head yahoo_data.csv ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Date,Open,High,Low,Close,Adj Close,Volume 2015-01-02,55.459999084472656,55.599998474121094,54.2400016784668,55.150001525878906,55.150001525878906,1664500 2015-01-05,54.540000915527344,54.95000076293945,52.33000183105469,52.529998779296875,52.529998779296875,2023000 2015-01-06,52.54999923706055,53.93000030517578,50.75,52.439998626708984,52.439998626708984,3762800 2015-01-07,53.31999969482422,53.75,51.7599983215332,52.209999084472656,52.209999084472656,1548200 2015-01-08,52.59000015258789,54.13999938964844,51.7599983215332,53.83000183105469,53.83000183105469,2015300 2015-01-09,55.959999084472656,56.9900016784668,54.720001220703125,56.06999969482422,56.06999969482422,6224200 2015-01-12,56.0,56.060001373291016,53.43000030517578,54.02000045776367,54.02000045776367,2407700 2015-01-13,54.470001220703125,54.79999923706055,52.52000045776367,53.18000030517578,53.18000030517578,1958400 2015-01-14,52.79999923706055,53.68000030517578,51.459999084472656,52.20000076293945,52.20000076293945,1854600 ``` ::: ::: And of course we can likewise read a ``.csv`` file into a dataframe. This is probably the most common way you will get data into Pandas. ::: {#dd55b5aa .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = pd.read_csv('yahoo_data.csv') df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}
Date Open High Low Close Adj Close Volume
0 2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500
1 2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000
2 2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800
3 2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200
4 2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300
``` ::: ::: ## Working with data columns In general, we'll usually organize things so that rows in the dataframe are __items__ and columns are __features__. ::: {#ac923208 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` Index(['Date', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Adj Close', 'Volume'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: Pandas allows you to use standard python __indexing__ to refer to columns (eg features) in your dataframe: ::: {#f411f82f .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} df['Open'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` 0 55.459999 1 54.540001 2 52.549999 3 53.320000 4 52.590000 ... 246 27.950001 247 28.270000 248 28.120001 249 27.950001 250 28.580000 Name: Open, Length: 251, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Pandas also allows you to use a syntax like an object attribute to refer to a column. But note that the column name cannot include a space in this case. ::: {#fc8c4166 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.Open ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` 0 55.459999 1 54.540001 2 52.549999 3 53.320000 4 52.590000 ... 246 27.950001 247 28.270000 248 28.120001 249 27.950001 250 28.580000 Name: Open, Length: 251, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: You can select a list of columns: ::: {#c42d2e1b .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['Open','Close']].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
Open Close
0 55.459999 55.150002
1 54.540001 52.529999
2 52.549999 52.439999
3 53.320000 52.209999
4 52.590000 53.830002
``` ::: ::: Putting things together -- make sure this syntax is clear to you: ::: {#f0a7a543 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.Date.head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` 0 2015-01-02 1 2015-01-05 2 2015-01-06 3 2015-01-07 4 2015-01-08 5 2015-01-09 6 2015-01-12 7 2015-01-13 8 2015-01-14 9 2015-01-15 Name: Date, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: ::: {#bcfb3124 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.Date.tail(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` 241 2015-12-16 242 2015-12-17 243 2015-12-18 244 2015-12-21 245 2015-12-22 246 2015-12-23 247 2015-12-24 248 2015-12-28 249 2015-12-29 250 2015-12-30 Name: Date, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: Changing column names is as simple as assigning to the ``.columns`` property. Let's adjust column names so that none of them include spaces: ::: {#a6d352df .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_column_names = [x.lower().replace(' ','_') for x in df.columns] df.columns = new_column_names df.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 251 entries, 0 to 250 Data columns (total 7 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 date 251 non-null object 1 open 251 non-null float64 2 high 251 non-null float64 3 low 251 non-null float64 4 close 251 non-null float64 5 adj_close 251 non-null float64 6 volume 251 non-null int64 dtypes: float64(5), int64(1), object(1) memory usage: 13.9+ KB ``` ::: ::: (Be sure you understand the __list comprehension__ used above -- it's a common and important way to process a list in python.) Now **all** columns can be accessed using the **dot** notation: ::: {#fa556ce0 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.adj_close.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` 0 55.150002 1 52.529999 2 52.439999 3 52.209999 4 53.830002 Name: adj_close, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ## A sampling of DataFrame methods. A dataframe object has many useful methods. Familiarize yourself with dataframe methods -- they are very useful. These should be self-explanatory. ::: {#8f188201 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"slide"}' execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['high', 'low', 'open', 'close', 'volume', 'adj_close']].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ``` high 3.809084e+01 low 3.659777e+01 open 3.732426e+01 close 3.733303e+01 volume 3.501135e+06 adj_close 3.733303e+01 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#7916c192 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"slide"}' execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['high', 'low', 'open', 'close', 'volume', 'adj_close']].std() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` high 1.138931e+01 low 1.114006e+01 open 1.128846e+01 close 1.126194e+01 volume 4.152341e+06 adj_close 1.126194e+01 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#e85df321 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"slide"}' execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} df[['high', 'low', 'open', 'close', 'volume', 'adj_close']].median() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` high 3.909000e+01 low 3.665000e+01 open 3.822000e+01 close 3.818000e+01 volume 2.356000e+06 adj_close 3.818000e+01 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#88dd8ae2 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"slide"}' execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.open.mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` 37.3242629229785 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#797f260e .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.high.mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ``` 38.09083672633684 ``` ::: ::: ### Plotting methods Pandas has an extensive library of plotting functions, and they are very easy to use. These are your "first look" functions. (Later you will use specialized graphics packages for more sophisticated visualizations.) ::: {#342e261a .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.high.plot(label='High') df.low.plot(label='Low') plt.title('YELP Stock Price') plt.ylabel('Dollars') plt.legend(loc='best'); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-21-output-1.png){width=585 height=431} ::: ::: ::: {#40beba7a .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"slide"}' execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.adj_close.hist() plt.xlabel('Adjusted Closing Price') plt.ylabel('Dollars') plt.title('YELP'); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-22-output-1.png){width=585 height=449} ::: ::: ### Bulk Operations Methods like ``sum()`` and ``std()`` work on entire columns. We can run our own functions across all values in a column (or row) using ``apply()``. As an example, let's go back to this plot: ::: {#f992c525 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.high.plot(label='High') df.low.plot(label='Low') plt.title('YELP Stock Price') plt.ylabel('Dollars') plt.legend(loc='best'); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-23-output-1.png){width=585 height=431} ::: ::: It's __almost__ perfect. The only problem is the $x$-axis: it should show time. To fix this, we need to make the dataframe __index__ -- that is, the __row labels__ -- into dates. We have a problem however: the "dates" in our data are only __strings__. We need Pandas to understand that they are actually dates. ::: {#6aafb1a2 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.date.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ``` 0 2015-01-02 1 2015-01-05 2 2015-01-06 3 2015-01-07 4 2015-01-08 Name: date, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: To convert each string in the ``date`` column to an actual date we will use ``.apply()``: ::: {#d332f1d7 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df = df.copy() new_df.date = df.date.apply(lambda d: datetime.strptime(d.split()[0], "%Y-%m-%d")) new_df.date.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` 0 2015-01-02 1 2015-01-05 2 2015-01-06 3 2015-01-07 4 2015-01-08 Name: date, dtype: datetime64[ns] ``` ::: ::: Each row in a DataFrame is associated with an index, which is a label that uniquely identifies a row. The row indices so far have been auto-generated by pandas, and are simply integers starting from 0. Fixing this is as easy as assigning to the `index` property of the DataFrame. ::: {#eaf7e4cc .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.index = new_df.date new_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ```{=html}
date open high low close adj_close volume
date
2015-01-02 2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500
2015-01-05 2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000
2015-01-06 2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800
2015-01-07 2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200
2015-01-08 2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300
``` ::: ::: Now that we have made an index based on a real date, we can drop the original `date` column. ::: {#2ff60cde .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df = new_df.drop(['date'],axis=1) new_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume
date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500
2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000
2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800
2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300
``` ::: ::: Now we can see that Pandas handles these dates quite nicely: ::: {#e0527cec .cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.high.plot(label='High') new_df.low.plot(label='Low') plt.title('YELP Stock Price') plt.ylabel('Dollars') plt.legend(loc='best'); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-28-output-1.png){width=585 height=432} ::: ::: ### Accessing rows of the DataFrame So far we've seen how to access a column of the DataFrame. To access a row we use a different notation. To access a row by its index value, use the **`.loc()`** method. ::: {#811802c9 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.loc[datetime(2015,1,23,0,0)] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ``` open 5.466000e+01 high 5.564000e+01 low 5.430000e+01 close 5.519000e+01 adj_close 5.519000e+01 volume 1.636400e+06 Name: 2015-01-23 00:00:00, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: To access a row by its sequence number (ie, like an array index), use **`.iloc()`** ('Integer Location') ::: {#37519f19 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.iloc[0,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=29} ``` open 5.546000e+01 high 5.560000e+01 low 5.424000e+01 close 5.515000e+01 adj_close 5.515000e+01 volume 1.664500e+06 Name: 2015-01-02 00:00:00, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: To iterate over the rows, use **`.iterrows()`** ::: {#4bf14fce .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} num_positive_days = 0 for idx, row in df.iterrows(): if row.close > row.open: num_positive_days += 1 print("The total number of positive-gain days is {}.".format(num_positive_days)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` The total number of positive-gain days is 125. ``` ::: ::: ## Filtering It is easy to select interesting rows from the data. All the operations below return a new DataFrame, which itself can be treated the same way as all DataFrames we have seen so far. ::: {#e06d9269 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} tmp_high = new_df.high > 55 tmp_high.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=31} ``` date 2015-01-02 True 2015-01-05 False 2015-01-06 False 2015-01-07 False 2015-01-08 False Name: high, dtype: bool ``` ::: ::: Summing a Boolean array is the same as counting the number of **`True`** values. ::: {#e41b11e8 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} sum(tmp_high) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ``` 11 ``` ::: ::: Now, let's select only the rows of **`df1`** that correspond to **`tmp_high`** ::: {#b7f16936 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df[tmp_high] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=33} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume
date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500
2015-01-09 55.959999 56.990002 54.720001 56.070000 56.070000 6224200
2015-01-12 56.000000 56.060001 53.430000 54.020000 54.020000 2407700
2015-01-22 53.869999 55.279999 53.119999 54.799999 54.799999 2295400
2015-01-23 54.660000 55.639999 54.299999 55.189999 55.189999 1636400
2015-01-26 55.119999 55.790001 54.830002 55.410000 55.410000 1450300
2015-01-27 56.060001 56.160000 54.570000 55.630001 55.630001 2410400
2015-01-28 56.150002 56.150002 52.919998 53.000000 53.000000 2013100
2015-02-03 53.830002 55.930000 53.410000 55.779999 55.779999 2885400
2015-02-04 55.529999 57.070000 55.250000 56.740002 56.740002 2498600
2015-02-05 57.599998 57.700001 56.080002 57.470001 57.470001 4657300
``` ::: ::: Putting it all together, we have the following commonly-used patterns: ::: {#accafccb .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} positive_days = new_df[new_df.close > new_df.open] positive_days.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=34} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume
date
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300
2015-01-09 55.959999 56.990002 54.720001 56.070000 56.070000 6224200
2015-01-16 50.180000 51.490002 50.029999 51.389999 51.389999 2183300
2015-01-21 51.200001 53.500000 51.200001 53.410000 53.410000 3248100
2015-01-22 53.869999 55.279999 53.119999 54.799999 54.799999 2295400
``` ::: ::: ::: {#e06502e4 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} very_positive_days = new_df[(new_df.close - new_df.open) > 4] very_positive_days.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=35} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume
date
2015-05-07 38.220001 48.73 38.220001 47.009998 47.009998 33831600
``` ::: ::: ## Creating new columns To create a new column, simply assign values to it. Think of the columns as a dictionary: ::: {#2bcb0a2f .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df['profit'] = (new_df.open < new_df.close) new_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=36} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume profit
date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500 False
2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000 False
2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800 False
2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200 False
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300 True
``` ::: ::: Let's give each row a ``gain`` value as a categorical variable: ::: {#603868bf .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} for idx, row in new_df.iterrows(): if row.open > row.close: new_df.loc[idx,'gain']='negative' elif (row.close - row.open) < 1: new_df.loc[idx,'gain']='small_gain' elif (row.close - row.open) < 6: new_df.loc[idx,'gain']='medium_gain' else: new_df.loc[idx,'gain']='large_gain' new_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume profit gain
date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500 False negative
2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000 False negative
2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800 False negative
2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200 False negative
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300 True medium_gain
``` ::: ::: Here is another, more "functional", way to accomplish the same thing. Define a function that classifies rows, and **`apply`** it to each row. ::: {#cf1667df .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} def namerow(row): if row.open > row.close: return 'negative' elif (row.close - row.open) < 1: return 'small_gain' elif (row.close - row.open) < 6: return 'medium_gain' else: return 'large_gain' new_df['test_column'] = new_df.apply(namerow, axis = 1) ``` ::: ::: {#ac5d5c8e .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=39} ```{=html}
open high low close adj_close volume profit gain test_column
date
2015-01-02 55.459999 55.599998 54.240002 55.150002 55.150002 1664500 False negative negative
2015-01-05 54.540001 54.950001 52.330002 52.529999 52.529999 2023000 False negative negative
2015-01-06 52.549999 53.930000 50.750000 52.439999 52.439999 3762800 False negative negative
2015-01-07 53.320000 53.750000 51.759998 52.209999 52.209999 1548200 False negative negative
2015-01-08 52.590000 54.139999 51.759998 53.830002 53.830002 2015300 True medium_gain medium_gain
``` ::: ::: OK, point made, let's get rid of that extraneous `test_column`: ::: {#b6d0d589 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_df.drop('test_column', axis = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=40} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Grouping An **extremely** powerful DataFrame method is **`groupby()`**. This is entirely analagous to **`GROUP BY`** in SQL. It will group the rows of a DataFrame by the values in one (or more) columns, and let you iterate through each group. Here we will look at the average gain among the categories of gains (negative, small, medium and large) we defined above and stored in column `gain`. ::: {#87fead39 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=41} ``` {.python .cell-code} gain_groups = new_df.groupby('gain') ``` ::: Essentially, **`gain_groups`** behaves like a dictionary: * the keys are the unique values found in the `gain` column, and * the values are DataFrames that contain only the rows having the corresponding unique values. ::: {#b5cd6af2 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=42} ``` {.python .cell-code} for gain, gain_data in gain_groups: print(gain) print(gain_data.head()) print('=============================') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} print('The average closing value for the {} group is {}'.format(gain, gain_data.close.mean())) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` The average closing value for the large_gain group is 47.0099983215332 The average closing value for the medium_gain group is 39.72307696709266 The average closing value for the negative group is 37.38476184057811 The average closing value for the small_gain group is 36.53367346160266 ``` ::: ::: ## Other Pandas Classes A DataFrame is essentially an annotated 2-D array. Pandas also has annotated versions of 1-D and 3-D arrays. A 1-D array in Pandas is called a `Series`. A 3-D array in Pandas is created using a ``MultiIndex``. To use these, read the documentation! ## Comparing multiple stocks As a last task, we will use the experience we obtained so far -- and learn some new things -- in order to compare the performance of different stocks we obtained from Yahoo finance. ::: {#b2859634 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=44} ``` {.python .cell-code} stocks = ['ORCL', 'TSLA', 'IBM','YELP', 'MSFT'] stock_df = pd.DataFrame() for s in stocks: stock_df[s] = pd.DataFrame(yf.download(s,start='2014-01-01',end='2014-12-31', progress = False))['Close'] stock_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=44} ```{=html}
ORCL TSLA IBM YELP MSFT
Date
2014-01-02 37.840000 10.006667 177.370941 67.919998 37.160000
2014-01-03 37.619999 9.970667 178.432129 67.660004 36.910000
2014-01-06 37.470001 9.800000 177.820267 71.720001 36.130001
2014-01-07 37.849998 9.957333 181.367111 72.660004 36.410000
2014-01-08 37.720001 10.085333 179.703629 78.419998 35.759998
``` ::: ::: ::: {#4982d7af .cell execution_count=45} ``` {.python .cell-code} stock_df.plot(); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-46-output-1.png){width=575 height=412} ::: ::: Next, we will calculate returns over a period of length $T,$ defined as: $$ r(t) = \frac{f(t)-f(t-T)}{f(t)} $$ The returns can be computed with a simple DataFrame method **`pct_change()`**. Note that for the first $T$ timesteps, this value is not defined (of course): ::: {#6429fb60 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=46} ``` {.python .cell-code} rets = stock_df.pct_change(30) rets.iloc[25:35] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=46} ```{=html}
ORCL TSLA IBM YELP MSFT
Date
2014-02-07 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2014-02-10 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2014-02-11 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2014-02-12 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2014-02-13 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2014-02-14 0.003700 0.320653 -0.009918 0.321849 0.012379
2014-02-18 0.009304 0.361995 -0.018485 0.355897 0.013817
2014-02-19 0.010675 0.317279 -0.016398 0.254880 0.038195
2014-02-20 0.011096 0.405798 -0.028728 0.257501 0.036803
2014-02-21 0.010074 0.385510 -0.027558 0.170875 0.062081
``` ::: ::: Now we'll plot the timeseries of the returns of the different stocks. Notice that the `NaN` values are gracefully dropped by the plotting function. ::: {#14c415cb .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"-"}' execution_count=47} ``` {.python .cell-code} rets.plot(); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-48-output-1.png){width=590 height=412} ::: ::: ::: {#e3a86125 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=48} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.scatter(rets.TSLA, rets.YELP) plt.xlabel('TESLA 30-day returns') plt.ylabel('YELP 30-day returns'); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-49-output-1.png){width=600 height=429} ::: ::: There appears to be some (fairly strong) correlation between the movement of TSLA and YELP stocks. Let's measure this. The correlation coefficient between variables $X$ and $Y$ is defined as follows: $$ \text{Corr}(X,Y) = \frac{E\left[(X-\mu_X)(Y-\mu_Y)\right]}{\sigma_X\sigma_Y} $$ Pandas provides a dataframe method to compute the correlation coefficient of all pairs of columns: **`corr()`**. ::: {#7a365cb3 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=49} ``` {.python .cell-code} rets.corr() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=49} ```{=html}
ORCL TSLA IBM YELP MSFT
ORCL 1.000000 0.007218 0.026666 -0.083688 0.131830
TSLA 0.007218 1.000000 0.196371 0.769623 0.411348
IBM 0.026666 0.196371 1.000000 0.104705 0.343697
YELP -0.083688 0.769623 0.104705 1.000000 0.264703
MSFT 0.131830 0.411348 0.343697 0.264703 1.000000
``` ::: ::: It takes a bit of time to examine that table and draw conclusions. To speed that process up it helps to visualize the table. We will learn more about visualization later, but for now this is a simple example. ::: {#cccac583 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=50} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.heatmap(rets.corr(), annot=True); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-51-output-1.png){width=533 height=416} ::: ::: Finally, it is important to know that the plotting performed by Pandas is just a layer on top of `matplotlib` (i.e., the `plt` package). So Panda's plots can (and often should) be replaced or improved by using additional functions from `matplotlib`. For example, suppose we want to know both the returns as well as the standard deviation of the returns of a stock (i.e., its risk). Here is visualization of the result of such an analysis, and we construct the plot using only functions from `matplotlib`. ::: {#28d40f06 .cell slideshow='{"slide_type":"fragment"}' execution_count=51} ``` {.python .cell-code} # plt.scatter(rets.mean(), rets.std()); plt.xlabel('Expected returns') plt.ylabel('Standard Deviation (Risk)') plt.xlim([-.05,.1]) plt.ylim([0,.3]) for label, x, y in zip(rets.columns, rets.mean(), rets.std()): plt.annotate( label, xy = (x, y), xytext = (30, -30), textcoords = 'offset points', ha = 'right', va = 'bottom', bbox = dict(boxstyle = 'round,pad=0.5', fc = 'yellow', alpha = 0.5), arrowprops = dict(arrowstyle = '->', connectionstyle = 'arc3,rad=0')) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](02B-Pandas_files/figure-html/cell-52-output-1.png){width=612 height=434} ::: ::: To understand what these functions are doing, (especially the `annotate` function), you will need to consult the online documentation for matplotlib. Just use Google to find it.
